What abnormalities do you visualize in the patient's OCT image?

![](/content/media/retina2-q1.png)
questions.title: Question 1

answers.explanation:
![](/content/media/retina2-q1a.png)

1. Hyper-reflective layer on the inner limiting membrane
2. Intra-retinal cystic changes

![](/content/media/retina2-q1a.png)

​​This case demonstrates a mild epiretinal membrane (ERM).
​
ERM is avascular, fibrocellular tissue that forms on the inner surface of the retina as a result of glial and hyalocyte proliferation at the vitreoretinal interface. 
​
On OCT, the ERM appears as a hyper-reflective layer. The foveal contour is preserved.

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: Given the patient's history and OCT image, which management strategy is the best course of action?

answers.answerText: A. Intravitreal Injection of Anti-Fibrotic Agent

answers.explanation:
![](/content/media/retina2-q1a.png)

The patient has a mild ERM confirmed on OCT with good visual acuity. Observation would be the correct option in this case.​
​
Vitrectomy may be useful in managing certain cases of ERM associated with significant visual acuity loss and disabling metamorphopsia. The decision to perform surgery should not be made based solely on OCT findings.

answers.answerText: C. Vitrectomy Surgery in the Affected Eye Only
D. Vitrectomy Surgery in Both Eyes

title: Case 2
description: 77F presenting with decreased vision and metamorphopsia OD
patientPresentation: A 77-year-old female with a history of retinal detachment presents with decreased visual acuity and metamorphopsia in her right eye. Visual acuity is 20/30 in the affected eye and she is not overly bothered by the metamorphopsia. The patient's OCT is shown below.
footer:
### Learning Objectives:​

1. Identify OCT findings associated with epiretinal membrane​.
2. Identify macular pseudohole as a common association with epiretinal membrane on OCT.
